text:
So let's get started. Let me welcome everybody to
the section I diploma ceremony.

As you may know,
we are not supposed to refer to this as a
commencement ceremony.

We can call it
graduation, diploma. The tentative plan
by the university is that you will have a
commencement ceremony on campus

hopefully about a year from now. But you are now official alums
of Harvard Business School,

so congratulations. And I hope we all do
get to get back together in a year or so to do
something in person.

I'm going to make a few
comments right at the beginning. And for those of you
who are on the stream, I'll introduce myself
in just a second.

And then we've got a couple
of great little videos we want to show you. Videos featuring
some of you, in fact.

So let me just start
with just a few comments.

I know I've had a number
of closing sessions with the section. You know, at the end
of LCA, conversations

with the leadership,
section chair, and all that. But I tried to
think of something that might be useful
to put in front of you

at the very, very end. And I came up with an
interesting perspective

on your two-year
experience at the school. And I know you're
looking forward.

You should be looking forward. That's fantastic. You've got a lot
to look forward to.

But I want to spend just
a minute looking back with you a little bit. And one reason that I think
I have a lot of confidence

in what the members of this
section will accomplish and what the members of
this class will accomplish

is because of the extraordinary
two years you've spent here. And I have special confidence
in the students in the section

because a lot of you quite well. But as a class, you
have really been

through what I would describe
as a unique Harvard MBA program.

You started out with
the first, I don't know, five, six months with
the classic program.

You know, beautiful campus. Lots of great people to meet. Lots of wonderful
social activities,

travel opportunities. You know, what's
called the HBS bubble. And it's a spectacular bubble.

I've never, once I got in
the bubble in the late 1970s, I've never left the bubble.

It's a splendid thing, OK? And then all of that ended
really abruptly last March.

And as I've been thinking about
the rest of your experience, it seems to me that one
way you can look at it

is to say that you really
started a second MBA program.

An MBA program that's
probably unique in the history of the school and one
that could have shaped you

in a number of powerful ways. Hey, professor. We've got a lot of
people waiting still.

Still waiting? Oh. Yeah. And how come they're
still waiting? Wow.

I don't think I can
admit them here. Cindy, can you let folks
in from the waiting room?

Yep, I'm still letting
people in who just joined. And there are some names
that don't match the roster, so I'm just trying to
make sure that I'm only
letting in section I folks. All right. Well, let's stop here.

I may just do a
brief repeat of-- sorry, I thought
almost everybody was
in with some folks doubled up.

And apparently, only people
who were in the section are supposed to be
in this session.

Everybody else is
supposed to stream.

All right. We are at 12 in
the waiting room. 11. [INAUDIBLE]

This session was very,
very carefully planned as we plan everything
here, but I don't think we

took into account the
dean running over and then

really restricting who can
be in the section Zoom room.

I can make a couple of
observations about the ceremony this morning.

I thought with what
Ruth Simmons said was quite striking to be
at a historically Black

college saying to
Harvard University and other elite
wealthy institutions,

we really need your help. What can you do? Saying it with the
president there and most of the people who are
overseers and fellows I thought

was a strong and
courageous message, and I suspect there will be
some follow-through on that.

I thought the music was-- the musical breaks
were really well done. We have so many
talented students here.

I have to also admit that I
really liked the Latin oration.

Every year, it is
like an introduction of just sort of utter
absurdity into what

is a traditional, perfectly
orchestrated ceremony.

But you've got this guy,
or a woman in some cases, waiving his or her arms in
this very demonstrative,

old-fashioned, oratorical style. And between what you
can read at the bottom

where they've got captions
for the translation and the choice of words that
the Latin Scholars often use,

you can almost understand
some of what they're saying as they were saying it.

I was curious about
how he translated words like pixel and computer.

And there were a couple
of odd words in there that I'm not sure how he did.

Also, I really do hope the
university can make good on its commitment to have a
commencement ceremony for all

of you in the yard. It's just sort of the yard
is packed with people. Those of you who
graduated from the college

or maybe got other
Harvard degrees know this. There's flags everywhere. No matter what the
weather's like,

there's this extraordinarily
festive spirit. And so I hope we'll actually
be able to recreate that.

Another problem with the-- let me see. Is everybody here,
you think, Cindy?

I just let everybody in
from the waiting room.

And I'll boot people
if there's somebody who should be in the
friends and family stream. OK. Well, let me go let me just--

yeah. Let me get back and
give a brief overview and welcome to those
of you who got in late.

Sorry things worked
out that way. So basically, what I
want to do is spend

just a couple of minutes,
five or six minutes, kind of looking
back with you, not looking forward, and
looking at what I think

is a really
extraordinary, probably unique in the
history of the school

MBA program that you had. And until we got to March
of last year, you know,

you've got the
classic HBS program. Lots of things to do. People to meet.

Endless social opportunities. You got to get your work done. Trying to find a way to cram
all those things into a day,

a week, into your life-- that's not a bad
problem to have. I remember one time--

this is years ago-- a friend
of mine came to visit me. I was living in
Soldiers Field Park.

And we got up Saturday
morning, and I said, well, let's go see the
Business School campus. So we were standing in
front of Baker Library.

And I said, well, so what
do you think of the campus? And he said, well,
I'd really like to see the Business School.

And I said, well, this
is the Business School. And we went back
and forth like this. It was kind of awkward.

And then I realized
that he was asking which building of the many
buildings he could see

was the Business School. And so I had to
explain to him we had lots of buildings,
beautiful buildings.

It's a spectacular place. As I mentioned
earlier, it's so nice that I've never
actually left it.

You had that experience. And then there was January,
2020, and everything changed.

And my view-- think
about this for yourself. But one way of thinking about
your experience since then

is that you, since
March of 2020, had the regular HBS curriculum.

Finished out the RC. You chose the courses you
wanted in your elective. It was awkward being online.

Got some hybrid classrooms. Good. But you had a second,
parallel curriculum.

An unplanned curriculum. And I think if you
think about some of the courses, if you
will, in this curriculum,

it was really an
extraordinary experience. So there was one course
called The Global Pandemic.

Where did it come from? Why is it here? What is it changing? Shortly after that, in the
beginning of the summer,

we had US national and
some international case studies on race.

Racial justice. Speaking as an American
and as an older American, there was an intensity
and focus on these issues

that we haven't seen in this
country since the 1960s. It was hard to miss that.

The pandemic ripped away a lot
of veneers about inequality and inequality in this
country and showed

the disproportionate burden
that some people were bearing. There was another case study
about stunning technological

progress. These mRNA, Messenger
RNA vaccines--

we may have only seen
the beginning of those. They may, in the
next decade or two, affect so much of what
happens in our world.

We rapidly accelerated
some tentative, small-scale experiments in remote work.

I think, I hope, you
were looking closely at the brilliance
of some companies.

And I would single out Amazon. I know there's
critiques of Amazon. We can discuss it
for a long time.

But what they do on a
scale with a quality level, logistically in terms of IT,
is just absolutely stunning.

There was another case study in
intense political polarization. That isn't over.

There's another
case study going on in what happens in a
society where there is very little trust in any
of the institutions that have

been so important in the past. And we are now conducting
in this country,

to a lesser extent
in other countries, these unparalleled experiments
in central bank financing.

Zero interest rates
as far as the eye can see and maybe
massive deficit spending

by the federal government. These aren't little Harvard
Business School case studies that you wrap up in 80 minutes.

These have just started. They are complicated. They're going to continue. And they intruded
into your lives
in lots of different ways. We all lived them. We thought about them. We talked about them.

And I'd also add one other thing
about this extraordinary last 14 months. It impacted a lot of
people personally.

You know, at the beginning,
there was an ominous threat. Maybe not so much to young
people, but to family members.
Older people in your families. How far would the virus spread? How contagious was it really?

How lethal was it really? A lot of you had
dream summer jobs that

disappeared or got shrunk down. In terms of section
experience, you

may have had fewer
large-scale section gatherings despite our rules and guidance.

Some students have said maybe
that led to fewer deeper relationships I don't know.

I don't think any
of you really know. I think we could have a
good discussion of this. But you really had
two curriculum's

here at Harvard Business School. And I think and I hope
that as time goes by,

you and I and the
others in the faculty may get some sense of
the difference they make.

Did they make you more
sensitive to risk? More willing to act
despite uncertainty?

More sensitive to people who
turn out to be vulnerable? More aware that you
can be more vulnerable?

More aware of what can be
accomplished just by scrambling and trying things?

These are immense, social,
economic, political case studies they can be interpreted
in a variety of ways.

And I think that's been a
unique part of your experience. The only comparable MBA
experience I can think of here

was really not an
MBA experience, but during World War
2, for four years, we basically trained
military officers.

You have had a
unique experience. And my bet is that
it's going to make you

more resilient, stronger, more
sensitive, more aware of risk.

More willing to take risks. More sensitive to the
extraordinary developments

going on in technology,
broadly defined.

I think it could have been
a extraordinarily valuable experience, even though I
know that at many points

along the way, it was hard
and difficult for you. So that's why I put the
tentative proposition

in front of you that I have even
more confidence in your class and in you and section I since
I know the students in section I

quite well that you will
make something of this, and you will accomplish
a lot based on it

and contribute a
lot based on it. So those are my words. My sort of final words for you
to think about as time goes by.

And maybe we could even
have a little classroom case study when we get
together in a year or so when you're back for
your first year reunion

and your commencement ceremony. So now, the next thing
we're going to do

is show you a short
video, Jan Rivkin talking a little bit about today.

And then we'll get back together
for a diploma ceremony, OK? So I will disappear for a moment
here and be back to you soon.

Congratulations again
to the class of 2021.

You are now officially
HBC graduates. You know, graduation day is
my favorite day of the year.

I love seeing our
students so happy. I love seeing their
families and friends so rightly proud of their
graduates and so excited

about their bright futures. And we now come to
my favorite part of my favorite day of the
year-- the diploma ceremony,

where we recognize each and
every member of your section. As members of the class
of 2021 are recognized,

you'll hear mention of
three kinds of honors. The first is distinction. This is for students who
earned academic honors

in both the first year and the
second year of our program. The second is high distinction.

These individuals not
only earned honors in the first year
and the second year. They also had a combined
academic performance

that placed them in the top
5% of their class as a whole. These students are also known
as George F. Baker Scholars,

commemorating the individual
whose generosity in the 1920s allowed us to build the campus.

I invite you to look
at the Baker Scholars page on the graduation
website to learn more about the legacy of George
Baker and this particular

distinction. Third and last, but by no
means least, the Dean's Award.

The Dean's Award celebrates
the extraordinary achievements of graduating students who,
during their time at HBS,

made distinctive contributions
to Harvard, to Harvard Business School, or the
broader community.

These students have contributed
to the well-being of others through amazing
acts of leadership.

Students and all
members of the community nominate these individuals,
and then Dean Datar makes the final selection.

So please enjoy the
diploma ceremony. Celebrate each and every
member of your section.

I hope that your section
will remain closed through the years, as mine has. And I hope that these
two years at HBS

will be just the beginning of an
ongoing conversation among you as you enjoy the long, happy
years of making differences

that are meaningful to you
and meaningful for the world. Be well, and stay close.

So the MBA program
has put together what looks to me like
a first-rate version

and online version of
a diploma ceremony. We're going to start it
in just a minute what

I would ask you to do is
imagine that you were outside in Baker Beach.

You're standing in a line with
your fellow section mates. You're going to walk
across the platform.
I'd shake your hand. The dean would shake your hands. Others would shake your hands. And then you'd walk down.

And you've got your diplomas. As I said, we want to
do this again in person,

but enjoy our online
diploma ceremony. I've had a look at it,
and it really is terrific.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[READING NAMES]

Well, I hope you enjoyed that. As I said, I watched
it a couple times, and I hope we can incorporate
some version of that

into our future traditional
in-person commencement

ceremonies. You really get to see the
students in the section

and get a good look at them
before everybody disperses in different directions.

We have one more piece of video
that we'll show in a moment. And it has sort
of the same goal,

except the focus
isn't so much on all of you who are the graduates
who have worked hard.

It's on the folks
in your families and groups of friends
and communities

who've supported you. And in some ways, it's almost
as important as the video

you just finished seeing
of your section mates. So let's have a look at this.

And each one of the pages
has several different photos. Try to get a good look.

There's a lot that's
really important captured in these photos of
families, friends, supporters.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So you've been a great section. I think just saw some of the
reasons, some of the people

who helped make you
a great section. And I think can continue to be
a great section even though you

are now dispersing. So I will plan on
seeing you whenever
URL here on campus next. I hope that's in a year or so.

I hope we can do
something in a classroom and see what you've all learned,
how the world looks to you,

and what you've learned
in the subsequent years. So I'm now going
to say farewell. My last recommendation
is that everybody unmute,

and you have a long round
of applause for each other, for everybody in section
I, and for all the families

and friends who have supported
you on your journey here. See you in a year or so.
Have a great year. [CHEERING AND APPLAUSE]
